headline.main: The Rise, Fall and Possible Renewal of a Town in Laos on China’s Border
headline.print_headline: Rise, Fall and Future of Laotian Town in China’s Embrace

docs.snippet: Boten, a onetime casino boomtown with thousands of visitors a month, is trying to come back, this time without gambling....
docs.abstract: Boten Journal; Laotian government entities and private investors from China hope $1.5 billion development called Beautiful Boten Specific Economic Zone in Boten, Laos, will bring tourism back to area following collapse of Chinese casinos and gambling halls there.
docs.lead_paragraph: Boten, a onetime casino boomtown with thousands of visitors a month, is trying to come back, this time without gambling.

docs.snippet: BROWN--Dr. Roscoe C., Jr. The members of One Hundred Black Men, Inc, mourn the loss of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., one of our founding members and former Presidents. As one of the original Tuskegee Airmen, former President of Bronx Community College...
docs.lead_paragraph:
BROWN--Dr. Roscoe C., Jr.

The members of One Hundred Black Men, Inc, mourn the loss of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., one of our founding members and former Presidents. As one of the original Tuskegee Airmen, former President of Bronx Community College, CUNY Executive and a talk show host, Dr. Brown was a living legend, and not only a fixture in Black History but a great American icon. We will miss his fierce leadership and limitless courage. Our sympathies are with his family. Michael Garner, President

docs.snippet: O'HEARN--Walter D. Jr., of New York and Southampton, NY died peacefully on July 5th. He was 81. A devoted family man, Walter leaves his beloved wife of 53 years, Denise, and his three daughters, Meghan Benedict (Douglas), Kelly Evans (Jeffrey), an...
docs.lead_paragraph: O'HEARN--Walter D. Jr., of New York and Southampton, NY died peacefully on July 5th. He was 81. A devoted family man, Walter leaves his beloved wife of 53 years, Denise, and his three daughters, Meghan Benedict (Douglas), Kelly Evans (Jeffrey), and Mary Harris (Richard). He is also survived by his three sisters, Eileen O'Hearn, Neill Miller and Julie Taminiau and his brother, Peter O'Hearn. He is also survived by his seven grandchildren. Walter graduated from Portsmouth Priory, Williams College, New York Law School and New York University Graduate School of Law. He began his career with King and O'Conor, a law firm in New York. He became President of McGrath Services Corporation. He then became a partner in Keane Securities, which later merged into Rafferty Capital Markets. Walter was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and the Lost Tree Club in North Palm Beach. His family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Friday, July 8th from 3pm to 6pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of his life at the Basilica Church of Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, Southampton, NY on Saturday, July 9th at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Wiener Family Palliative Care Unit at Mt. Sinai Hospital, NY.

docs.snippet: BROWN--Roscoe C., Jr. The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., whose devotion to country, community, and public service inspired all who knew him. After serving as president of Bronx Community College, Dr. Bro...
docs.lead_paragraph:
BROWN--Roscoe C., Jr.

The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Dr. Roscoe C. Brown, Jr., whose devotion to country, community, and public service inspired all who knew him. After serving as president of Bronx Community College, Dr. Brown found his academic home at the Graduate Center, leading the Center for Urban Education Policy with his characteristic vigor and passion. His was a life of uncommon courage and integrity, and we join our CUNY colleagues in extending our deepest condolences to his family and friends. Chase F. Robinson, President, The Graduate Center

after a brave fight, died of cancer with his companion Charlotte and his brother Jim present. Charlotte and his daughters will welcome his friends on Friday, July 8th at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th Street, NYC, from 3pm-5pm.

docs.snippet: SLATER--Selma Terner. Forever Young. Beloved mother of Michael and Richard Weber, predeceased by her parents Ida and Louis Terner, sister of the late Emanuel, Sylvia, Beatrice, William, and widow of Louis Slater. A cherished aunt and grand aunt an...
docs.lead_paragraph:
SLATER--Selma Terner.

Forever Young. Beloved mother of Michael and Richard Weber, predeceased by her parents Ida and Louis Terner, sister of the late Emanuel, Sylvia, Beatrice, William, and widow of Louis Slater. A cherished aunt and grand aunt and a generous philanthropist to charities and causes both large and small, in New York City and Palm Beach. Graveside Service will be held on Friday, July 8, 10:30am at Beth David Cemetery Elmont, NY for further information please call Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" at 212-288-3500.

on July 5, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Izzy. Loving mother of David Levine, Carol and Jeffrey Goldberg. Cherished grandmother of Samantha, Justin and Susie. Devoted great-grandmother of Julian, Emily, Sophie, and Ivy. Adored sister of Gerald and Delores Michael and Helen Levine.

docs.snippet: MARSHALL--Louis, age 93, died in his home in Houston, TX on July 5, 2016. He was born in Manhattan, NY November 22, 1922, the third child of Bessie and Max Marshall. He was raised in Brooklyn, NY. He completed his B.S. in Chemical Engineering at C...
docs.lead_paragraph:
MARSHALL--Louis,

age 93, died in his home in Houston, TX on July 5, 2016. He was born in Manhattan, NY November 22, 1922, the third child of Bessie and Max Marshall. He was raised in Brooklyn, NY. He completed his B.S. in Chemical Engineering at City College of New York in 1944 with highest honors. At CCNY he served as president of the student chapter of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers and as treasurer of the Tau Beta Pi chapter (the honorary fraternity for engineering). Lou had two extraordinary passions, engineering and family. Lou approached engineering with an abiding curiosity that drove him to unravel phenomena that many would not even notice. He had a methodical attention to detail - careful analysis of multiple possibilities - and a keen awareness of how a given plant design could go wrong. As a chemical engineer, he initially worked as a plant operator for Shell Oil, but moved to a position with Lummus Engineering in 1950 to focus on petrochemical plant design, his passion. He remained with Lummus for 35 years, where he became known as the "Engineer's Engineer." His colleagues looked to Lou as a trouble shooter who could determine the source of problems and devise solutions. At his retirement dinner, a younger colleague said that he learned more about engineering from Lou Marshall than from his entire university training. Early on, Lou recognized the power of the digital computer to transform the practice of chemical engineering. He pioneered some of the first uses of linear programming to optimize petrochemical plant operation, and did initial work applying nonlinear programming to similar problems. After retiring from Lummus in 1986, he continued an extensive consulting practice applying linear optimization techniques to petrochemical plant operation. Lou's other great passion was his family. In 1945 he married his best friend and college sweetheart, Faith Gladstone. Their 71 years of marriage were an inspiration to all who knew them. In addition to being survived by Faith, Lou is also survived by their two children, Ellen Ruth Marshall, attorney in Orange County, CA (Robert Arnold, attorney), and David Aaron Marshall, economist in Chicago, IL (Maija Freimanis, physician) and their two grandchildren, Astrid Carla Marshall, medical student in Manhattan, NY (Jefferson Li, business student) and Max Benjamin Marshall, jazz pianist in New York. Lou served as a role model for his children and grandchildren, encouraging a passion for science and math, and conveying his deep love of music, photography, and woodworking. In a letter to his children on the occasion of his 90th birthday, he wrote, "If Mom and I have been examples to you in the way we have lived our lives, then I am doubly satisfied." The family acknowledges with special gratitude the loving care provided by Catalina Alvarez in recent years. The funeral will be held Friday, July 8, 2016 at 11am at the Proler Family Chapel at Beth Israel Memorial Gardens Cemetery, 1101 Antoine, Houston, TX. The family requests that any remembrances be made as memorial contributions to Congregation Beth Israel, Houston, TX, or to an educational or charitable organization of your choice.
